questions.text: Which of the following is not a measure of location?
questions.solution:
Percentile is a measure of position. It can be defined as a number that states the percentage of observations that fall below any particular score.

Measures of location help in summarizing the data by locating its centre or middle. The three main measures of location include mean, median and mode. They are also called measures of central tendency.

Related Pearl: Measures in Statistics

Measures used in statistics

Definition

Examples

Measures of Location or Central Tendency

These measures summarize the data by defining the centre or the middle.

An entire distribution can be characterized by these measures which represent all the observations.

Mean, median, mode

Measures of Dispersion or Variability or Spread

These measures help in determining the extent to which data is stretched or squeezed.

Range, interquartile range, variance, standard deviation

Measures of Position

These measures give the position of specific data in relation to other data in the set.

Percentiles, quartiles, centiles,  z scores

questions.text: The mean can be calculated only if data is on:
questions.solution:
The mean can be worked out only for quantitative values. Thus, it can be calculated for interval or ratio scale data. 

A dichotomous scale is a type of nominal scale data that can take only two values. Example: Male/ Female. For nominal scale data, the preferred measure of central tendency is mode. For ordinal scale data, both median and mode can be calculated.

Median can be derived from ordinal, interval and ratio data scales. Mode can be derived from all scales of data- nominal, ordinal, interval and ratio.

  • The arithmetic mean responds to the exact value of every element in the distribution.
  • This makes it over-sensitive to extreme values, i.e., outliers thus making it an inappropriate measure for skewed distributions.
  • The advantage of the arithmetic mean is that if repeated samples are taken from the same populations, they will have very similar means, i.e., the measure of central tendency that best resists the influence of fluctuation between samples is the mean.
  • The mean can be calculated only on quantitative data on an interval or a ratio scale.

questions.text: During a school health survey on malnutrition, the children are arranged according to ascending order of their heights. Which of the following can be obtained by this arrangement?
questions.solution:
The 50th centile can be obtained when values are arranged in order and the central value is picked out. This is the same as the median.

In a distribution that has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value.

In a distribution that has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the middle values, i.e., the arithmetic mean of the two middle values.

An example of how to calculate the median of an odd and an even number of elements is given below.

Option C: Geometric mean is obtained by taking the arithmetic mean of values on a logarithmic scale.

Option D: Mean deviation is a measure of dispersion. The average of deviations from the arithmetic mean gives the mean deviation.

Related Pearl: The Median in Biostatistics

  • The median is the central element in a distribution when all the elements are arranged in order.
  • In a distribution that has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value.
  • In a distribution that has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the middle values, i.e., the arithmetic mean of the two middle values.
  • The median is not sensitive to extreme values, i.e., outliers and thus it is preferred measure of location for very skewed distributions.
  • The drawback of the median is that it doesn’t respond to the actual values of the elements but only to the number of values above or below it.
  • The median is the same as the 50th centile.
  • It is sometimes symbolized by Mdn.
  • The median can be arrived at in ordinal, interval and ratio data scales.

questions.text: Which of the following can have more than one value?
questions.solution:
The mode of a given sample can have more than one value. It is the most frequently occurring value in a distribution. 

For example, in the sample [1, 3, 6, 6, 6, 6, 7, 7, 12, 12, 17], the most repeated value i.e., the mode is 6.

For the list of data [1, 1, 2, 4, 4], the mode is 1 and 4. Therefore, the mode is not unique. This dataset may be said to be bimodal, while a set with more than two modes may be described as multimodal.

Median can have only one value, obtained by arranging values in order and then picking out the central value. In a sample with an even number of elements, median is obtained by taking the average of the middle 2 elements.

Mean can only have a single value. The harmonic mean is the reciprocal of the arithmetic mean of the reciprocals of the data values. The geometric mean is obtained by taking the arithmetic mean of values on a logarithmic scale.

Related Pearl: The Mode in Biostatistics

  • A distribution with a single mode is called unimodal.
  • If two values occur with the highest frequency, then the distribution is bimodal.
  • If more than two values occur with the highest frequency, then the distribution is multimodal.
  • The mode is the preferred measure of central tendency for nominal data.
  • It is sometimes symbolized by Mo.
  • Mode can be arrived at from all data scales, i.e., nominal, ordinal, ratio and interval.

questions.text: While collecting data on which of the following variables would median not be the preferred measure of central tendency?
questions.solution:
Blood pressure usually forms a normal symmetrical distribution for which mean is the preferred measure of central tendency.

Distributions of survival time, incubation period and health expenses have the probability of having extreme values, i.e., outliers. Thus, they form skewed distributions and in such cases, median is the preferred measure of central tendency.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true for the given distribution of ages of patients who are visiting a family planning clinic in a day?

Age in years: 20, 31, 31, 31, 25, 28, 35, 38, 31.
questions.solution:
The arithmetic mean from the following data is given by the sum of all the values, 270 divided by the number of values, 9 = 30.

The data can be arranged in ascending order as 20, 25, 28, 31, 31, 31, 31, 35, 38.

After arranging in order, the median is obtained by picking out the central value which is 31.

The mode is the most frequently occurring value, which is 31 here.

questions.text: You are conducting a study on birth weights in your hospital. Out of 11 births, 5 babies weighed over 2.5 kg, one baby weighed 2.5 kg and 5 weighed less than 2.5 kg. What does the value 2.5 represent in this distribution?
questions.solution:
Out of the 11 birth weights, 2.5 kg would represent the middle value or the median. 5 babies weigh more than 2.5 kg and 5 less than that.

This can be understood from the image below.

Option A: Mean or arithmetic mean is the average value. In this case, the mean is the average of all the 11 values. It need not be 2.5.

Option B: Geometric mean is obtained by taking the arithmetic mean of values on a logarithmic scale.

Option D: Quartile is a measure of position, where the data is divided into four equal sets. 3/4 of the values are below the 3rd quartile reading. Hence, it cannot be the central reading.

questions.text:
You are conducting an epidemiological study on malaria in a town X. The number of cases reported during the last 10 years is given below. What is the most appropriate measure of central tendency for this data?
Year 

No. of cases
2011 250
2012 320
2013 190
2014 300
2015 5000
2016 100
2017 260
2018 350
2019 320
2020 160
questions.solution:
In this scenario, median is the preferred measure of central tendency as there are outliers.

The value of 5000 is an outlier in the given set, i.e., an observed value which is very distant from other observations in the distribution. This indicates the usage of median as the measure of central tendency as it is not sensitive to extreme values, unlike the mean.

By arranging the data in order: 100, 160, 190, 250, 260, 300, 320, 320, 350, 5000, we get the median as (260 + 300) / 2 = 280.

Options A and B: Mean is the most affected by the presence of outliers. Mode is the least affected by outliers but it is used mainly for measuring the central tendency of nominal data.

Option D: Geometric mean can be used for datasets with extreme values but it is not used when the values can be zero or negative. In the given scenario, the number of malaria cases reported in a town can also have a zero value.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Positively (right) skewed distribution

  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).

  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.

questions.text: During a school health assessment, the mean value of weight for a group of 10 boys was found to be 18.2 kg. Later, it was found that the weight of one of the boys was wrongly recorded as 2.0 kg instead of 20 kg. What is the true mean weight of the group?
questions.solution:
The true mean weight of the group is 20 kg.

Mean is given as x̄ = ∑x / n, where n is the number of elements and ∑x denotes the sum of all the elements in the series.

In this scenario, the incorrect mean is 18.2, i.e.,
∑x / 10 = 18.2, making ∑x = 182.
But this is incorrect as one of the 10 weights was wrongly recorded as 2 instead of 20.

The corrected ∑x = (Incorrect ∑x – incorrect value) + correct value.

The incorrect sum of all elements = 182, incorrect value =2 and the correct value = 20.

Thus, the correct sum of all the 10 weights would be, 
∑x = (182 – 2) + 20 = 200.

From this, the correct mean value of the 10 weights can be given by: 
∑x / 10 = 200/ 10 = 20.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is correct about the given distribution of ages of patients attending a geriatric medicine clinic?

Age in years: 70, 70, 76, 76, 80, 83, 84, 85
questions.solution:
For the given dataset, the modes are 70 and 76. The mode is the most frequently occurring value. It can have multiple values. In this scenario, the values 70 and 76 have been repeated twice. 

Median of this distribution is the central value, (76 + 80) / 2 = 78.

questions.text:
The smoking history for the past 6 years of a patient with emphysema is given in the table below. If a pack has 20 cigarettes, what is the mean, median and mode of the given data?
 Year   No of cigarettes per day
2015 Quarter pack
2016 Half a pack
2017 Half a pack
2018 Half a pack
2019 One pack
2020 Two packs
questions.solution:
The distribution in this scenario in terms of the number of cigarettes smoked is 5, 10, 10, 10, 20, 40.

The mean here is ∑x/n = 95/6 = 15.833 rounded off to 16.

The median here is the central value = average of 3rd and 4th values since the distribution has an even number of values. This comes to (10 + 10) / 2 = 10.

The mode here is 10 which has a frequency of 3 in the given dataset.

questions.text: While reviewing a data distribution, you find that the highest value of 58 was wrongly recorded as 85 and so you correct it. How will this correction change the measures of central tendency?

choices.text: No change in mean, decreased median
Decreased mean, no change in median

questions.solution:
The given change in a dataset would cause a decrease in the mean but the median would remain unchanged.

The mean is sensitive to every value in the distribution. Since the correct value of 58 is much lesser than the wrongly recorded value of 85, the final mean will be decreased compared to the earlier recorded value.

However, as only the highest value was wrongly recorded, the median i.e., the central value, will remain the same.

questions.text:
While conducting a study on the age at death in males of a population Y, the distribution curve given below is obtained. Which of the following is true?
  1. It is a positively skewed distribution
  2. It is a left skewed distribution
  3. Mean > median > mode
  4. It is a bimodal distribution
  5. Mean < median < mode
questions.solution:
The given image shows a negatively skewed or a left-skewed distribution curve. Here, mean < median < mode.

Mode is the most frequently occurring value in the distribution and is given by the highest point of the graph. Since the given graph has only one peak, it is unimodal.

A positively skewed distribution refers to a right-skewed distribution. In such cases, mean > median > mode.

  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

questions.text: Which of the following sets of measures of central tendency is likely to match the distribution depicted in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a right-skewed or positively skewed distribution. So, among the given options, the most likely values of mean = 3, median = 2, and mode = 1.

We can tell the direction of skew of a distribution by observing the direction of the tail. Here, the tail of the distribution is towards the positive direction and thus it is positively skewed or right-skewed. In a positively skewed distribution, mean > median > mode. 

If the tail of the distribution is towards the negative direction, the distribution would be negatively skewed or left-skewed. In such distributions, mode > median > mean.

questions.text: You are conducting a study on blood pressure in a population. The systolic blood pressure values have a mean of 130 mmHg, a median of 140 mmHg and mode of 160 mmHg.  What type of distribution is this?
questions.solution:
This is a unimodal negatively skewed distribution.

In this scenario, the mean of 130 mmHg is less than the median of 140 mmHg which is less than mode of 160mmHg. Since mean<median<mode, this is an asymmetrical negatively skewed or left-skewed distribution.

It is a unimodal distribution as there is only a single value for mode.

In a symmetrical distribution, the mean = median = mode.

In a positively skewed distribution, mean > median > mode.

questions.text: The mean of a dataset is 2 and the median is 3. What is the mode?
questions.solution:
As the mean ≠ median, this is an asymmetric distribution and so we can use the formula:

Mode = 3 median - 2 mean.

Using the given values, mode = (3x3) – (2x2) = 9 – 4 = 5.

A distribution is termed symmetric when the mean, median and mode coincide i.e., mean= median= mode.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: Study A(red) and Study B(blue) done in a given population yields two different distribution curves as shown below. Comparing both the curves, which of the following will be true?

choices.text: Mean = median, not equal to mode
Mode = median, not equal to mean

questions.solution:
On comparing the 2 graphs, we can say mean=median for both study A and B but the mode is different.

Study A is a unimodal symmetrical distribution, so mean=median=mode.

Study B is a bimodal distribution. Here, mean=median, but the curve has two highest points, therefore it has 2 modes.
